segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Hello, everyone. My name is Kuba Gretzky. Do we see the slides? Okay, I think it worked
before. Okay, nevermind. My name is Kuba Gretzky. I am an independent contractor. I do reverse
engineering, software developer, security researcher. Basically, I started around ten
years ago. I started by reverse engineering massive multiplayer online games. You know,
these ones where you hunt boars and sit in the forest and just hack one by one. So, basically,
I made an automation tool that allowed the player to move by himself. And then it collected
loot and everything like that. But today, I want to talk exactly about my Wi-Fi project,
which is basically a penetration testing device, something like the Pineapple but with a bit
of a twist. So, basically, the whole presentation will be a live demo, so there is nothing
that can go wrong. So, as you can see on the stage right over here, this is like a
spider-looking device. It's a proof of concept right now. I don't have like a custom case
for it. So, basically, it just looks what it looks like. So, this is like the main control
panel. So, this thing actually is for the red teamers. Probably there are a lot of penetration
testers around here that may be willing to use this kind of thing. And basically, you
keep this thing in your backpack or I don't know, in your, you keep it concealed on yourself
and you can access it through your mobile phone. So, basically, you create an access
point on your mobile phone, it connects back to you with the in-built wireless adapter
and then it allows you to SSH into it and control it from your phone. Of course, the
phone screen is a little small, so it's for the people with good eyesight mostly. So,
right now, it's connected to my PC and this is the interface. So, basically, what I will
try to do here is that the option 3 is scanning all the nearby networks. This is mainly for
doing some recon on-site. I press enter to refresh all the networks that are around.
So, you can see there is a Salki, PPNT2, things like that that you have running on your phone.
And here are also the clients below. So, the clients will also show up the probes as
well if you have like a device that is actively looking for networks. So, that can give you
an idea what is your, where is the phone that you actually want to hijack or things like
that. And from here, you can actually add the targets. So, for example, we pick the
targets from all the clients that we have managed to see. So, I don't know, probably
some of these are yours. Okay, let's maybe pick something, I don't know, number 7. Of
course, I was told to not do any actual hacking because probably of some legal reasons. Probably.
Okay. So, yeah, basically, this is one feature. I'll try to keep it short because I don't
have much time. So, yeah, basically, you're able to scan for the devices, then you can
create your, you can connect to the network that you want by entering the password, of
course, and picking the SSID that you want to use. You can also create your own access
point that you will be using. So, here is the interesting part. I worked on the way
to tether the internet for all the users that connect back to your access point. So, basically,
you can share the internet connection either from your phone or through the wireless access
point that the other adapter is connected to. So, basically, one adapter is for monitoring,
so it uses scanning all the nearby networks. One is for active connection to any network
that you choose. And the third one is basically used for deauthentication. If you want to
deauthenticate any client and make them connect back to your network, which you have a password
for or not, then it's perfect. So, basically, here, yeah, I don't have actually any internet
connection on my PC, so I'll just control C from it. So, basically, the main, you may
say it's similar to Wi-Fi Pineapple, right? But the main, like, thing that is at the core
of this tool is the HTTP proxy that I wrote in C++, and I tried to make it as efficient
as possible because there were solutions like Ethercap before. There is Bettercap in Ruby,
but I wanted my own that is written in C++, which is fast, efficient, and actually is
able to pass all the requests and make them go through like in a blast. So, that thing
you actually can see, so I'll actually demonstrate how the attacks look like when you're already
on the network or you have clients connected back to you on your network that you have
hosted. So, okay, so this is the interface that was made just in case the live demo goes bad.
Okay, so this is an active attack. You can make actually any computer that uses HTTP connection
to be redirected to the fake browser update page. This is like custom made for every browser,
Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer. You can see in the address bar there is download Google.com,
so it looks pretty legit except for the no HTTPS, naturally. This can be tricky to implement,
actually. I haven't found a way to do it, but then it automatically downloads an exe file,
then on Firefox looks like this, and basically, this is like a stub, this exe file. This is a
custom software that I wrote. This is simply a downloader which downloads the real update from
the Internet, and after it downloads, it executes PowerShell, so you can implement it with Empire
or something like that. It's pretty simple. And the other attack is this actually will redirect
every visitor to a fake Google login page, and you can see the domain is actually accounts.google.com.w
because it cannot be Google.com because of HSTS protection, which actually makes all modern
browser force HTTPS on known domains, like Google.com. It's like sent in the response
from the servers. So basically, I had to change the domain to make it look similar but still be
different, do the DNS spoofing, then SSL stripping, and it actually proxies the real Google sign-in
page back to the user, so actually, when they log in, put all their credentials, the credentials
are intercepted, and as well, the session token cookies. So then you have full control over the
person's account. So basically, you can even connect from a different IP address, and you can use the
account as its own. Yeah, so basically, I'll show maybe a bit more. How much time do we have still?
Okay. Okay, so do I have still something to show you? Sorry for a low quality of slides, but I had
like one hour before the party yesterday to prepare it. So yeah, basically, you can also plug in a modem
to it, so you can use the modem to actually share the internet connection. And right now, let's see
if it connects. It's using WVDial. Yep, seems it worked. Or not. Yeah, sometimes, unfortunately, I have an
issue with this feature. So basically, my idea is to present, I don't know still what to do with this tool.
So I may release it at some point, or I may not. And basically, it will be to help to be used by penetration
testers to ease their job. And basically, I wanted to show it to you to get feedback from you, just so that you
can tell me what else would you like me to implement or things like that. Of course, I plan to add the
responder to it to intercept the SMB requests and things like that. But yeah, we have some time. Yeah, okay.
Final slide. Oh yeah, and also important thing. There's the other project Evil Jinx that I released a couple of
weeks ago and made a big update the day before yesterday. This actually, the thing that I showed you for proxying
the real Google website and capturing the credentials and with the cookies, this is actually the method that uses
the NGINX server to do it remotely. So if you like, you can check it out. It's free and completely modular.
So thank you.
If you have any questions. Okay, first question here.
Have you thought about or maybe already added a WPS query?
WPS. Yeah, actually, there is also, I haven't showed it, but there is a Wi-Fi cracker that is actually with my own
updates because it hasn't been updated for several years. And it actually does the reaver to crack the WPS things.
Also, it captures the handshakes and things like that. So yeah, it basically does everything by itself.
Yeah, unfortunately, too many people still have that carried on by default.
Yeah, exactly. But it depends on what kind of router you have to make it exploitable.
No more questions? Okay, thank you very much. I hope you enjoyed the presentation.
And hit me up afterwards so that I can give you some feedback, probably.
Thank you.
